Total Testosterone.description: A key male hormone responsible for muscle growth, energy, and overall health.

Free Testosterone.description: The active form of testosterone that is available for use in the body.

Estradiol.description: A type of estrogen that plays a role in reproductive health and bone strength.

Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG).description: A protein that controls how much testosterone and estrogen are available in the body.

Prolactin.description: A hormone involved in milk production and hormone balance.

Luteinizing Hormone (LH).description: A hormone that signals the testes or ovaries to produce testosterone or estrogen.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH).description: A hormone that helps with sperm production in men.

Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate (DHEA-S).description: A hormone that helps make other hormones like testosterone and estrogen.

Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA).description: A protein made by the prostate gland, used to check prostate health. If PSA is elevated but not drastically high, consider these non-cancerous causes: Recent ejaculation (PSA can rise for up to 48 hours after), Vigorous exercise or cycling (can increase PSA for 24-48 hours), Prostate infections or inflammation (prostatitis), Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) – common with aging, Urinary tract infections (UTIs), Recent digital rectal exam (DRE) or prostate biopsy. PSA naturally increases with age, so age-specific reference ranges can be useful: 40–49 years: 0–2.5 ng/mL, 50–59 years: 0–3.5 ng/mL, 60–69 years: 0–4.5 ng/mL, 70+ years: 0–6.5 ng/mL.

TSH.description: A hormone that controls how fast the thyroid works to regulate metabolism.

Free T3.description: An active thyroid hormone that controls energy use in the body.

Free T4.description: A thyroid hormone that helps control metabolism and energy levels.

Insulin-Like Growth Factor I (IGF-1).description: A hormone that helps with growth, muscle building, and metabolism.

HbA1c.description: A measure of blood sugar levels over the past three months.

Fasting Insulin.description: A hormone that controls blood sugar levels, measured after fasting.

Vitamin D (25-OH).description: A vitamin that helps with bone strength and immune health.

Glucose.description: A sugar in the blood that provides energy.

Calcium.description: A mineral important for strong bones and nerve function.

Sodium.description: A mineral that helps regulate water balance and nerve function.

Potassium.description: A mineral that helps with muscle function and heart health.

Chloride.description: A mineral that helps keep the body's acid-base balance.

Carbon Dioxide (CO\u2082), Total.description: A measure of the body's acid-base balance.

Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN).description: A waste product in the blood that checks kidney function.

Creatinine.description: A waste product from muscles that helps check kidney function.

BUN/Creatinine Ratio.description: A comparison of kidney function markers.

Total Protein.description: A measure of the total proteins in the blood, important for body functions.

Albumin.description: A protein that helps keep fluids balanced in the blood.

Globulin, Total.description: A group of proteins that help with immune function.

Albumin/Globulin (A/G) Ratio.description: A balance of two important blood proteins.

Total Bilirubin.description: A substance made when red blood cells break down, used to check liver function.

Alkaline Phosphatase.description: An enzyme that checks liver and bone health.

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST).description: A liver enzyme used to check liver health.

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT).description: An enzyme that checks for liver damage.

White Blood Cell (WBC) Count.description: A count of immune cells that fight infections.

Red Blood Cell (RBC) Count.description: A count of cells that carry oxygen.

Hemoglobin (Hgb).description: A protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.

Hematocrit (Hct).description: A measure of how much of the blood is made up of red blood cells.

Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV).description: A measure of the average size of red blood cells.

Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).description: The average amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells.

Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentratio.description: A measure of hemoglobin concentration in red blood cells.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW).description: A measure of variation in red blood cell size.

Platelet Count.description: A measure of cells that help with blood clotting.

Mean Platelet Volume (MPV).description: A measure of the average size of platelets.

Neutrophils.description: A type of white blood cell that fights infections.

Lymphocytes.description: A type of white blood cell that helps with immune defense.

Monocytes.description: A type of white blood cell that helps fight infections.

Eosinophils.description: A type of white blood cell involved in allergic reactions.

Basophils.description: A type of white blood cell involved in immune responses.

Total Cholesterol.description: A type of fat in the blood that affects heart health.

HDL.description: The 'good' cholesterol that helps clear fats from the blood.

LDL (calculated).description: The 'bad' cholesterol that can clog arteries.

Triglycerides.description: A type of fat that stores energy in the blood.

VLDL (calculated).description: A type of fat that carries triglycerides in the blood.

Total Cholesterol/HDL Ratio.description: A ratio used to assess heart disease risk.

LDL/HDL Ratio.description: A ratio of bad to good cholesterol.
